channel.title: Posts on Linked Data Benchmark Council
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on Linked Data Benchmark Council

item.title: Speeding Up LDBC SNB Datagen
item.description: LDBC’s Social Network Benchmark [4] (LDBC SNB) is an industrial and academic initiative, formed by principal actors in the field of graph-like data management.

item.title: LDBC Is Proud to Announce the New LDBC Graphalytics Benchmark Draft Specification
item.description: LDBC is proud to announce the new LDBC Graphalytics Benchmark draft specification.

item.title: LDBC and Apache Flink
item.description: Apache Flink [1] is an open source platform for distributed stream and batch data processing.

item.title: Elements of Instance Matching Benchmarks: a Short Overview
item.description: The number of datasets published in the Web of Data as part of the Linked Data Cloud is constantly increasing.

item.title: SNB Interactive Part 3: Choke Points and Initial Run on Virtuoso
item.description: In this post we will look at running the LDBC SNB on Virtuoso.

item.title: SNB and Graphs Related Presentations at GRADES '15
item.description: Next 31st of May the GRADES workshop will take place in Melbourne within the ACM/SIGMOD presentation.

item.title: SNB Interactive Part 2: Modeling Choices
item.description: ​SNB Interactive is the wild frontier, with very few rules. This is necessary, among other reasons, because there is no standard property graph data model, and because the contestants support a broad mix of programming models, ranging from in-process APIs to declarative query.

item.title: LDBC Participates in the 36th Edition of the ACM SIGMOD/PODS Conference
item.description: LDBC is presenting two papers at the next edition of the ACM SIGMOD/PODS conference held in Melbourne from May 31st to June 4th, 2015.

item.title: SNB Interactive Part 1: What Is SNB Interactive Really About?
item.description: This post is the first in a series of blogs analyzing the LDBC Social Network Benchmark Interactive workload.

item.title: Why Do We Need an LDBC SNB-Specific Workload Driver?
item.description: In a previous 3-part blog series we touched upon the difficulties of executing the LDBC SNB Interactive (SNB) workload, while achieving good performance and scalability.

item.title: Event Driven Post Generation in Datagen
item.description: As discussed in previous posts, one of the features that makes Datagen more realistic is the fact that the activity volume of the simulated Persons is not uniform, but forms spikes.

item.title: The LDBC Datagen Community Structure
item.description: This blog entry is about one of the features of DATAGEN that makes it different from other synthetic graph generators that can be found in the literature: the community structure of the graph.

item.title: Industry Relevance of the Semantic Publishing Benchmark
item.description: Publishing and media businesses are going through transformation I took this picture in June 2010 next to Union Square in San Francisco.

item.title: OWL-Empowered SPARQL Query Optimization
item.description: The Linked Data paradigm has become the prominent enabler for sharing huge volumes of data using Semantic Web technologies, and has created novel challenges for non-relational data management systems, such as RDF and graph engines.

item.title: Person Activity Subgraph Features in LDBC DATAGEN
item.description: When talking about DATAGEN and other graph generators with social network characteristics, our attention is typically borrowed by the friendship subgraph and/or its structure.

item.title: SNB Driver - Part 2: Tracking Dependencies Between Queries
item.description: The SNB Driver part 1 post introduced, broadly, the challenges faced when developing a workload driver for the LDBC SNB benchmark.

item.title: SNB Driver - Part 3: Workload Execution Putting It All Together
item.description: Up until now we have introduced the challenges faced when executing the LDBC SNB benchmark, as well as explained how some of these are overcome.

item.title: Running the Semantic Publishing Benchmark on Sesame, a Step by Step Guide
item.description: Until now we have discussed several aspects of the Semantic Publishing Benchmark (SPB) such as the difference in performance between virtual and real servers configuration, how to choose an appropriate query mix for a benchmark run and our experience with using SPB in the development process of GraphDB for finding performance issues.

item.title: Semantic Publishing Instance Matching Benchmark
item.description: The Semantic Publishing Instance Matching Benchmark (SPIMBench) is a novel benchmark for the assessment of instance matching techniques for RDF data with an associated schema.

item.title: Further Developments in SNB BI Workload
item.description: We are presently working on the SNB BI workload. Andrey Gubichev of TU Munchen and myself are going through the queries and are playing with two SQL based implementations, one on Virtuoso and the other on Hyper.

item.title: Sizing AWS Instances for the Semantic Publishing Benchmark
item.description: LDBC’s Semantic Publishing Benchmark (SPB) measures the performance of an RDF database in a load typical for metadata-based content publishing, such as the famous BBC Dynamic Semantic Publishing scenario.

item.title: DATAGEN: a Realistic Social Network Data Generator
item.description: In previous posts (Getting started with snb, DATAGEN: data generation for the Social Network Benchmark), Arnau Prat discussed the main features and characteristics of DATAGEN: realism, scalability, determinism, usability.

item.title: SNB Driver - Part 1
item.description: In this multi-part blog we consider the challenge of running the LDBC Social Network Interactive Benchmark (LDBC SNB) workload in parallel, i.

item.title: Making Semantic Publishing Execution Rules
item.description: LDBC SPB (Semantic Publishing Benchmark) is based on the BBC linked data platform use case.

item.title: Getting Started With the Semantic Publishing Benchmark
item.description: The Semantic Publishing Benchmark (SPB), developed in the context of LDBC, aims at measuring the read and write operations that can be performed in the context of a media organisation.

item.title: Choke Point Based Benchmark Design
item.description: The Linked Data Benchmark Council (LDBC) mission is to design and maintain benchmarks for graph data management systems, and establish and enforce standards in running these benchmarks, and publish and arbitrate around the official benchmark results.

item.title: New Website Online LDBC Benchmarks Reach Public Draft
item.description: The Linked Data Benchmark Council (LDBC) is reaching a milestone today, June 23 2014, in announcing that two of the benchmarks that it has been developing since 1.

item.title: Social Network Benchmark Goals
item.description: Social Network interaction is amongst the most natural and widely spread activities in the internet society, and it has turned out to be a very useful way for people to socialise at different levels (friendship, professional, hobby, etc.

item.title: Welcome to the New Industry Oriented LDBC Organisation for Benchmarking RDF and Graph Technologies
item.description: It is with great pleasure that we announce the new LDBC organisation site at www.

item.title: 2nd International Workshop on Benchmarking RDF Systems
item.description: Following the 1st International workshop on Benchmarking RDF Systems (BeRSys 2013) the aim of the BeRSys 2014 workshop is to provide a discussion forum where researchers and industrials can meet to discuss topics related to the performance of RDF systems.

item.title: DATAGEN: Data Generation for the Social Network Benchmark
item.description: As explained in a previous post, the LDBC Social Network Benchmark (LDBC-SNB) has the objective to provide a realistic yet challenging workload, consisting of a social network and a set of queries.

item.title: Getting Started With SNB
item.description: In a previous blog post titled “Is SNB like Facebook’s LinkBench?

item.title: Introducing SNB Interactive, the LDBC Social Network Benchmark Online Workload
item.description: The LDBC Social Network Benchmark (SNB) is composed of three distinct workloads, interactive, business intelligence and graph analytics.

item.title: Is SNB Like Facebooks LinkBench
item.description: In this post, I will discuss in some detail the rationale and goals of the design of the Social Network Benchmark (SNB) and explain how it relates to real social network data as in Facebook, and in particular FaceBook’s own graph benchmark called LinkBench.

item.title: Making It Interactive
item.description: Synopsis: Now is the time to finalize the interactive part of the Social Network Benchmark (SNB).

item.title: SNB Data Generator - Getting Started
item.description: In previous posts (this and this) we briefly introduced the design goals and philosophy behind DATAGEN, the data generator used in LDBC-SNB.

item.title: The Day of Graph Analytics
item.description: Note: consider this post as a continuation of the “Making it interactive” post by Orri Erling.

item.title: Using LDBC SPB to Find OWLIM Performance Issues
item.description: During the past six months we (the OWLIM Team at Ontotext) have integrated the LDBC Semantic Publishing Benchmark (LDBC-SPB) as a part of our development and release process.
